item.title: TD 1 : Improper Integrals
item.description: Revision Exercice $$I_0 = \int_0^1 \frac{x+1}{x^2+2x+2} dx = \int_0^1 \frac{1}{2}\frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x+2} dx = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^1 \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x+2} dx$$ We have here a primitive that we know : $$\int \frac{u'}{u} = \ln(|u|)$$ Hence the integral evaluates to : $$ \boxed{I_0 = \frac{1}{2}\Bigg[\ln\left(|x^2+2x+2|\right)\Bigg]_0^1 = \frac{1}{2}\left(\ln(5) - \ln(2)\right) = \frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{5}{2}\right)}$$ $$I_1 = \int_0^1 \frac{2x+1}{(x^2+x+1)^2} dx$$ We recognize the primitive : $$ n \neq -1, \int \frac{u'}{u^n} = -\frac{1}{(n-1)u^{n-1}}$$ Let's calculate $I_1$ : $$ \boxed{I_1 = \Bigg[-\frac{1}{1\times (x^2+x+1)^1}\Bigg]_0^1 = \Bigg[-\frac{1}{(x^2+x+1)}\Bigg]_0^1 = -\frac{1}{3} + 1 = \frac{2}{3}}$$
